title: Did Not Connect: Potential Security Issue
content:
Did Not Connect: Potential Security Issue

Firefox detected a potential security threat and did not continue to nrega.nic.in because this website requires a secure connection.

What can you do about it?

nrega.nic.in has a security policy called HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS), which means that Firefox can only connect to it securely. You can‚Äôt add an exception to visit this site.

Probably nothing, since it‚Äôs likely there‚Äôs a problem with the site itself.

title: Firefox Tabs GONE ‚Äî4th time in past year‚Äîfollowing MacBook Pro Restart!!!
content: The title sums it up. ‚Ä¢ Does anyone know why FFx , when opened following my MacBook Pro Restart, opens without any of my selected Tabs AND then provides no History of my last FFx session??? ‚Ä¢ Hours of Internet research, vanishes! It really p--- me off! ‚Ä¢ This has happened at least 4 or 5 times in the past year to year and a half and on both computers. And I do stay on top of my FFx updates. If a Notice appears on my screen, I usually install within 24 hours. ‚Ä¢ This last time (today) I had previously updated FFx a few hours earlier and then I needed to run a Restart of the computer.... ‚Ä¢ MBPro fires back up, I open FFx and nothing in the Tabs Header. GONE! Poof! ‚Ä¢ I go to Browsing History - no Restore Previous Session (by any other term) ‚Ä¢ Doesn't it seem logical? THAT fundamental function would be right there, top of the list?!?! ‚Ä¢ HERE IS THE KICKER: In FFx I opened the FFx "About Firefox" menu and noticed it says, amidst all the provided information, "Failed to check for updates." ‚Ä¢ BS! It was following the update that FFx Tabs vanished! How can it insert that statement? Was I suppose to do something other than click "OKAY". And then the new version begins when FFx is reopened. Right? ‚Ä¢ If this comes down to the older OS on the computer (10.13.6) I should not be receiving update notices from FFx. If so, a notice of, "Your Mac's OS is too old to run FireFox's latest version" would be what I should receive. So, as you can tell, I'm frustrated and baffled at the same time. Any thoughts? I would appreciate it. Thanks
creator: DWrightB

Customize this article Firefox Was this article helpful? Secure connection failed and Firefox did not connect Firefox Last updated: 11/30/24 45% of users voted this helpful

This article explains why you may see a Secure Connection Failed or a Did Not Connect: Potential Security Issue error page, and what you can do. 

   If you see a Warning: Potential Security Risk Ahead error page, see What do the security warning codes mean? and How to troubleshoot security error codes on secure websites.    To troubleshoot other error messages, see Websites don't load - troubleshoot and fix error messages.

Table of Contents 

   Secure connection cannot be established        Secure Connection Failed        Did Not Connect: Potential Security Issue    Website issues        TLS version unsupported        HSTS required    Security software conflict    Incorrect system clock    Other secure connection issues

Secure connection cannot be established

When a website that requires a secure (HTTPS) connection tries to secure communication with your computer, Firefox cross-checks this attempt to make sure that the website certificate and the connection method are actually secure. If Firefox cannot establish a secure connection, it will display a Secure Connection Failed or Did Not Connect: Potential Security Issue error page. Secure Connection Failed

A Secure Connection Failed error page will include a description of the error and a Try Again button. There is no option to add a security exception to bypass this type of error. bold text
